comment._content: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,581152,598449,7,9

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: David Hayes, Merchant: 58 in 1901. It's hard to gauge his age from this picture though.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: William Eager - 46, Thomas Mannix - 58, John Quinlan - 24. They're all shopkeepery sort of ages. I'd say this is quite close to the turn of the century. Quinlan can't have been in business much before this (Unless he inherited the business from another J, I suppose - his mother's still on the premises as head of family).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] What is L.B on the map, close to where our Baker Bicycle Shop is?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The bicycle merchant on the corner's not there in 1901 though. Neither on Queens Square nor Grubbs Quay.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Dunno. If it was Germany it'd be a Landesbank. You need an OSI expert like Niall.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gregcarey] They'd be cast iron; They probably rusted through.

comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: I'm just about old enough to remember the Royal Hotel, which was demolished in 1995 or thereabouts. The site was empty for the next decade or so before being replaced by a rather underwhelming building....

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: GoogleMaps says it is now Pearse Square.  Who was Pearse? Please excuse my ignorance.

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  Your ignorance is excused. The answer to who Pearse  was has kept academics and historians in good jobs for almost a hundred years. He was one of the leaders of the 1916 rebellion in Dublin. As the centenary approaches expect to hear a lot more about him. Great photo of Fermoy.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] We don't allow use of the word ignorance around here! :) Have a look here - click on Seven Signatories of the Proclamation...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

True!  But even to replace them with replicas would be nicer than the current monstrosities!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The letter box is a Protected Structure, so it is probably the same one now as on the OSI map (1903). I wonder if it is a V.R. pre-1901 or an E.R. post 1901?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think this AIB in streetview is the same as this Provincial Bank in the DIA, dated 1899.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Looks as if Richard Brangan Baker, Cycle Merchant did not live over the shop (from 1901 census).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75556178@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Thank you!  Older and wiser ...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
And here's why Mr Baker didn't live over the shop, 'twas only a branch depot! From the Southern Star on Saturday, 21 April 1900:
R.B. BAKER 44, King Street, Cork. BRANCH DEPOT-FERMOY. SOLE AGENT FOR "Centaur," "Humber," "Swift," "Premiers," "Sparkbrook," "Cleveland" Cycles
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Punch had alterations done in 1896. The current buidling has "Established 1851" in plaster, instead of the signage seen here. So, I think this is before 1896. [Edit: wrong! see below]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The three buildings noted by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] as 1908 were rebuilt after a fire, according to the DIA.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Hang on, Niall. "Established 1851" on Google Streetview is on the Daniels' premises (3rd one into the square), not Punch surely?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Oops! Daniels is less help: the DIA shows his shop was rebuilt in 1908 after the fire.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: If you've any seeking energy left, would any of you like to try your skills on a Paul Henry? Would love to know where this was painted/sketched from (please excuse me while I tuck away my dangling preposition)
